Award.AwardTitle: ICES: Small: Auctions and Optimizations in Ad Exchanges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Viewers who browse web pages on the Internet are shown display ads such as images and video. Traditionally, web page publishers and advertisers negotiate a priori through sales teams to determine which ads are shown. An emerging way to buy and sell display ads is via automated ad exchanges, which are marketplaces where publishers and advertisers trade ad impressions via real time auctions. This project explores computational, informational and economic aspects of such ad exchange markets. It will abstract suitable models for such markets and study the fundamental challenges, including problems in auction design, online optimization, risk-bounded pricing, real time bidding strategies, and even cryptography. Specific examples include the design of an optimal auction in the presence of a hierarchy of intermediaries who are also auctioneers, determining at each level of this hierarchy which intermediary to call for bids, and proving the integrity of auctions at each level of the hierarchy. Solving these problems requires new methods, concepts and tools from Economics, Finance and Optimization, and Computer Science.

Ad exchanges will impact nearly every user on the Internet. Progress on research challenges described here has the potential to directly impact such systems and the experience of nearly every user on the Internet. Further, facing the technical challenges will bring together Computer Scientists and Economists, and also push these disciplines to address very high performance challenges. For example, auction and optimization solutions have to work in tens of milliseconds, the time it takes for users to experience a web page access. This calls for new algorithmic techniques beyond the current start of the art. Finally, a detailed analysis of the role of information in ad exchanges-how much or little information is relevant for the working of the marketplace-is of great interest to Internet users and ultimately the society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to understand the optimizations and mechanisms used in various online ad markets such as sponsored search and display advertising, in particular, via intermediaries such as ad exchanges. Since nearly every online activity of users at large is impacted by ads, understanding their nature is important to the society at large. 

Our work studied and quantitatively described how ads are targeted (is display ads via user profiles, in social ads via intermediate online users, in videos via content of ads seen), how user information is passed around via intermediaries (using cookies and other mechanisms and how extensive are these), how ads can be allocated effectively (not only to maximize revenue but also secondary goals of advertisers, or allocated to restrict the number of ads users see), how pricing of the ads varies (due to education and other factors in social networks like LinkedIn and Facebook and how different data granularity affects ad prices), what are emerging structures of ad markets (social recuritment ad markets are new as are vertical ad markets for travel, hotel, products etc that are significantly different from common ad markets like sponsored search), and what are potential models of interaction between the various players in ads ecosystem (budget feasible mechanisms for learning or models of collaboration). Taken together, the outcomes use tools from algorithmic theory, optimization as well as data gathering, mining and IP networking. The outcomes are not only interesting for researchers seeking to understand online ads, but also other communities including networking, data mining, Economics and others. Our study of how user data and profiles are used is of broader interest to any online user and society at large. 

The outcomes have been published in peer-reviewed conferences and have appeared in journals. Also, we have reached to large audiences and other communities via tutorials, summer school lectures and invited talks. Several students have been trained to become domain experts in online ads and the mathematical methods behind them.  The site https://sites.google.com/site/aucoptinadexchanges/ will continue to be maintained with updated material and is openly available.
